I believe that computational science relies on open code on data and subscribe to the [Manifesto put out by Jonathan B. Buckheit and David L. Donoho](https://statweb.stanford.edu/~wavelab/Wavelab_850/wavelab.pdf):

> An article about computational science in a scientific publication is not the scholarship itself, it is merely advertising of the scholarship. The actual scholarship is the complete software development environment and the complete set of instructions which generated the figures.
>
> -- <cite>Jonathan B. Buckheit and David L. Donoho</cite>

## ![](img/mofworld.png){width="10%"} Digital reticular chemistry -- ["MOFworld"](mof.world) 

I have been very active in developing tools for "digital reticular chemistry" (see also [this article by Yaghi and collaborators](https://www.cell.com/chem/fulltext/S2451-9294(20)30418-6)), i.e., tools for data-driven science with materials such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent-organic frameworks (COFs).
